title: Minutes of Meetings 2
text:
Minutes of Team Meeting
Date : Sunday, 2nd June 2025
Time : 10:30am-11:30am
Present:

Evangeline Olivia Sidiharto Kusumoputri
Patricia Trisno
Xu, Xinyi



Agenda Items

1. Module Prototyping Progress Review
Action: Each member shared updates on the module they are individually developing as part of the Mini-Challenge 1 prototype.
Discussion:

All members confirmed progress in module coding and visualization.
Xinyi focused on implementing temporal influence dynamics using centrality scores over time.
Evangeline explored artists in the network and used a scoring system based on their collaborations, creative roles, and charted works to predict which ones are most likely to become rising stars.
Patricia explored visualizing collaboration density and node degree for genre evolution tracking.

Outcome: Modules are progressing well, and all team members are on track to finalize them before integration.


2. Shiny App Integration Planning
Action: Planned how individual prototype modules will be integrated into the final Shiny application.
Discussion:

Agreed to use a tab-based interface where each tab represents one analytical module.
Decided to define shared data inputs at the global level (server.R) and reuse across modules.
Discussed standardizing visual styling and color palettes for a consistent interface.

Outcome: Integration strategy confirmed. Final modules will be modularized using moduleServer() and UI() structure for Shiny compatibility.


3. Set up a shared Git repository for version control and backup.
Next Steps

Finalize each module individually.
Begin layout design of the poster over the weekend.
Schedule dry run of full Shiny app by 10th June.

Next Meeting Scheduled: Monday, 16th June (7:00 pm – 8:00 pm)

Folk


Fame


From Falk to Fame


Unveiling the Stories Behind Numbers

title: Minutes of Meetings 1
text:
ISSS608 Group 10 - Project Meeting Minutes

Minutes of Team Meeting
Date : Sunday, 2nd June 2025
Time : 10:30am-11:30am
Present:

Evangeline Olivia Sidiharto Kusumoputri
Patricia
Xu, Xinyi



Agenda Items

Understanding the Challenge and Dataset Scope Action: Reviewed the Mini-Challenge 1 brief and the dataset in knowledge graph format (nodes and links representing artists, albums, collaborations, and influence).

Discussion:
The dataset is semi-structured with nodes representing entities (e.g., Sailor, artists, songs, albums) and edges representing relationships (e.g., collaboration, influence, genre flow).
We identified key data fields likeNode Type, genre, Edge Type, and timestamp fields (release_date, notoriety_date).
Outcome:
Agreed to treat this as a network analysis and visualization problem centered around the career and influence of Sailor Shift, with temporal, stylistic, and relational dimensions.

Identifying Key Research Questions Action: Brainstormed questions aligned with the challenge deliverables. Based on different questions we are going to solve, we decided each person will take one question to analyze and then combine the analysis all together at the end.
Outcome: Team prioritized the following analytical goals:


Influence Network: Who influenced Sailor, and whom has she influenced directly or indirectly?
Collaborations: Who are her most frequent collaborators across time and genres?
Genre Flow: How has Oceanus Folk spread across the global music network?
Temporal Dynamics: Did the influence of Oceanus Folk rise gradually or intermittently?
Genre Evolution: How has Oceanus Folk itself changed under Sailor’s influence?
Rising Star Profile: What patterns (e.g., collaborations, genre shifts, notoriety timing) define an artist’s rise?

Forecasting: Predict the next three potential Oceanus Folk stars using network position and career paths.

Technical Challenges and Considerations Action: Identified data cleaning and modeling tasks.

Outcome:

Clean missing or malformed IDs in from and tofields.
Harmonize time fields and assign year-based bins for temporal analysis.
Categorize and recode Edge Types into weighted influence scores.
Validate node uniqueness and remove duplicates.

Next Steps Refine the visual storytelling narrative using exploratory findings.

Align each visualization with one or more of the challenge questions.
Begin drafting poster components with annotated visuals and insights.

Next Meeting Scheduled: 5th- June( 8 pm- 9 pm)

title: From Folk to Fame
text: In the rapidly evolving music industry, understanding how artists rise to fame and how genres expand their influence is a complex challenge. The story of Sailor Shift, a once-local Oceanus Folk singer who rose to global superstardom, offers a unique opportunity for us to examine this phenomenon. Her career not only redefined what it means to be a successful artist but also played a pivotal role in bringing the Oceanus Folk genre to international prominence.

title: From Folk to Fame
text:
4.1 Data Wrangling

4.1.1 Load the JSON graph
data <- fromJSON(“data/MC1_graph.json”)


4.1.2 Standardize and Clean Node Attributes

Handling missing values (e.g., stage names or display names)
Convert date fields to a consistent and usable format



4.1.3 Categorize Edge Types
Our team has agreed to group the relationships into the following categories:

Influence Edges: These include relationships that reflect stylistic or creative influence, such as DirectlySamples, CoverOf, InStyleOf, and related types.
Collaboration Edges: These refer to instances where artists work together on music-related projects, including roles like PerformerOf, ProducerOf, MemberOf, and others.

title: From Folk to Fame
text:
4.2 Network Construction

4.2.1 Full Graph Construction
We combined all available relationship types to build a full network that reflects the interconnected nature of the music industry.


4.2.2 Ego Network Extraction
To focus on Sailor Shift’s direct and indirect connections, we extracted ego networks centered on her node.

1st-degree connections: direct collaborators or influences
2nd- and 3rd-degree connections: indirect relationships (e.g., collaborators of collaborators)

title: From Folk to Fame
text:
4.3 Temporal Analysis

4.3.1 Time-Based Snapshots
To understand how influence and collaboration evolve over time, we plan to conduct a temporal analysis using key timestamp attributes in the dataset:

release_date: when a song or album was publicly released
written_date: when a work was originally created or composed
notoriety_date: when an artist or work began to gain significant attention



4.3.2 Genre Diffusion Tracking

New collaborations and influences forming
The growth of artist networks



4.3.3 Intermittent vs. Gradual Influence Patterns
We analyzed the frequency and consistency of influence relationships across time to distinguish between:

Intermittent influence: sharp, isolated bursts of impact (e.g., viral song)
Gradual influence: steady and persistent growth in artistic reach or style adoption

title: From Folk to Fame
text:
4.4 Centrality & Prediction
To identify key figures and forecast potential breakout artists, we computed centrality metrics on the constructed network:

4.4.1 Centrality Measures
We focused on the following network centrality indicators:

Degree Centrality: measures the number of direct connections an artist has, indicating collaboration frequency or direct influence.
Betweenness Centrality: quantifies how often an artist acts as a bridge in the network, highlighting their role in connecting different groups or genres.
PageRank: reflects both the number and quality of connections, emphasizing artists who are connected to other influential nodes.



4.4.2 Defining a Rising Star
The prediction model goes beyond measuring popularity alone. It captures a multi-dimensional view of artistic potential by evaluating the following core components:

Creative Activity
Regular releases suggest momentum and consistency.
Creative Contribution
Artists who engage in composition, production, or lyrics.
Collaboration
Any other person who is connected to the same song(s) as the artist via a creative roles.
Public Recognition
While not the only sign of influence, chart performance remains a strong indicator of public recognition.



4.4.3 Rising Star Score
We designed a composite Rising Star Score to quantify future potential. It includes the following weighted components:

Total Works
Reflects productivity and output volume.
Charted Ratio (highly weighted)
Measures public recognition; greater weight emphasizes impact over quantity.
Collaboration Count
Indicates the artist’s engagement in the music community.
Creative Contributions
Captures behind-the-scenes roles (e.g., producer, lyricist, composer).
Freshness Adjustment
Penalizes artists who have not released new work recently, even if they debuted early.
